div1.p: [Laura Carter] discusses her health and her new living situation.

div1.head: Letter from [Laura Armistead Carter] to William S. Thayer, January 6, 1931

opener.dateline:
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
January 6, 1931.

div1.p:
Re my physical condition. I am, I think, slowly acquiring some
physical endurance, although not at the rate I had hoped. I attribute this
mainly to the fact that the bladder trouble has been rather worse since
my return; about the same over-frequency and with more pain at these inter-
vals. Days before yesterday afternoon (Sun. Jan. 4th.) I began having
considerable continuous pain, from this trouble, which lasted (roughly)
two nights and a day. On the supposition that this pain might be caused
by acidity, to which a similar trouble at the Hopkins was, I believe, at-
tributed, I began taking a little sodium bicarb. after meals. This, as
a substitute for a “fizzy” medicine (powder) given me after meals during
the latter part of my stay at the Hopkins, after the continuous pain
above mentioned. I have had no pain since early this morning and, although
rather “limp” after a bad night feel able to go about a certain number
of my “lawful occasions.” If, however, you think that the “fizzy” powder
after meals would be better than the sodium bicarb., may I have the pre-
scription? I am, of course, taking the medicine Dr. Pierce gave me,
at your instance: Rx, No. 124464. It was extremely thoughtful to give me
a bottle of the medicine itself, but here again I as I have no copy of the
prescription, I am writing Dr. Pierce for it, as you said that you wished
me to take the medicine for a month and I do not wish to get out of it.

I am extremely desireous not to have to stop work again and am
taking all possible pains with myself, from this reason, as well as from
my deep appreciation of all that you have done for me and my desire to co-
operate in every way possible. It is by no means so easy, however, to re-
adjust oneself to the anxieties and complications of the “state of life”
to which I have returned, as it was to relax into the heavenly peace of
the Hopkins, adjusted to my particular needs. For instance, I came back
to find that Miss Brown has been having a series of “heart attacks,” for
during my absence, about which I am much concerned and about which I have
not yet been able to get her to see a doctor. Also, I've had to get up
data (re payments and non-payments) for a law suit for my cousin, who han-
dles my small financial affairs, work up a little material for the book
and reorganize our living arrangements--i. e. try getting meals at the café
instead of in our apartment: We will get better dinners and with less
trouble, but it will be more expensive. We will still get our own break-
fasts and lunches. I am still keeping up the milk between meals and
at about 8.30 at night.

I am finding it rather difficult to write, as two steam pipes
have broken in the wall of “my” part of the apartment! The atmosphere is
a bit “steamy” for concentrated narrative, and the constant telephone calls
from the Resident Manager, who promises “reinforcements” (carpenter, plum-
ber and electrician) while originally cheering are now merely tedious: the
above mentioned trio being already a half day overdue! Well, its all in
days work, and rather funny, even though uncomfortable.

Have not yet been to either Library, as I found some material I
could work up here and, frankly, haven't felt up to working away from the
apartment. I would have gone to-day, but for the bad weather and let the
Manager and the broken pipes “work out their own salvation.”

“The book” is already in the hands of the printers, Williams
and Wilkins of Baltimore. However, as I wrote Dr. Rutledge, I was able
to turn over to Dr. Frost nearly everything he wanted (prior to reading
proof) on the day I left the Hopkins. The few things I am working up
now can be handled in the galley proof.

With all manner of good wishes for yourself, Dr. and Mrs.
Rutledge and “Miss” Rutledge, I remain
